channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Indians Urged to Stay Indoors as Sweltering Heat Kills More Than 1,300
item.description: Most of the deaths were reported in the states of Andhra Pradesh and Telangana in southern India, as temperatures surpassed 116 degrees in some places.
item.dc:creator: NIDA NAJAR
item.media:description: Asphalt on the roads of New Delhi melted amid soaring temperatures.

item.title: U.S. Rebukes China on Efforts to Build Artificial Islands
item.description: Comments left little doubt that Washington shared the concerns of other Asian nations about China’s growing military presence in disputed areas of the South China Sea.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW ROSENBERG

item.title: Jinghong Journal: China’s High Hopes for Growing Those Rubber Tree Plants
item.description: With rubber prices at a 10-year low and farmers panicked over sinking incomes, officials say they have a rare opportunity to promote ideas to make the rubber industry more economically and environmentally sustainable.
item.dc:creator: BECKY DAVIS
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: Villagers collected the timber of unproductive rubber trees near Tuanjie, in southern China. A program aims to make the industry more sustainable.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Liao Ran on the Trial of Zhou Yongkang and China’s New Gang of Four
item.description: Liao Ran, a corruption analyst at Transparency International, discusses the fall of Zhou Yongkang, China’s former security chief, and the consolidation of power by President Xi Jinping.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:credit: Didi Kirsten Tatlow/The New York Times

item.title: Sunnis Fleeing ISIS Violence Find Few Doors Open in Iraq
item.description: Many Iraqi Shiites are looking with distrust at Sunni civilians displaced by attacks by Sunni militants in the Islamic State.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO
item.media:description: Iraqis escaping Islamic State fighters in Anbar Province crossed a bridge near Baghdad last week.

item.title: Decades Later, Germans Still Dread the Bombs That Didn’t Go Off
item.description: Unexploded ordnance, covered over in haste or in oversight, is cause for alarm — and for wide-scale evacuations — long after World War II has ended.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY
item.media:description: Residents lined up outside an evacuated nursing home in Cologne, Germany, on Wednesday, waiting for a World War II-era bomb to be defused.

item.title: Russian Political Activist Is Hospitalized With Mysterious Illness
item.description: Vladimir Kara-Murza’s role as an opposition activist raised suspicions of poisoning, but there was no confirmation of this from doctors or the authorities.
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: FIFA Arrests Come at a Time of Continued Swiss Cooperation
item.description: Switzerland, famously secretive, has gradually become more cooperative with foreign authorities as its banking sector and companies seek to expand and flourish abroad.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Outside FIFA headquarters in Zurich on Wednesday.

item.title: Russia Says FIFA Corruption Investigation Is No Threat to 2018 World Cup
item.description: Officials said the arrests of top FIFA officials would not derail Russia from hosting the World Cup in 2018.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW ROTH
item.media:description: Construction continued Wednesday on a soccer stadium in St. Petersburg, Russia, that is scheduled to host some of the 2018 World Cup matches.

item.title: Ruling Party in Ethiopia Appears Headed for Sweeping Victory
item.description: Preliminary results show the incumbent Ethiopian People’s Revolutionary Democratic Front and allies winning 442 of the 547 constituencies, including all of Addis Ababa.
item.dc:creator: JACEY FORTIN

item.title: Vatican Official Denounces Ireland’s Vote for Same-Sex Marriage
item.description: Cardinal Pietro Parolin, the Vatican secretary of state, said that the Irish referendum that legalized same-sex marriage was a “defeat for humanity.”
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: Muslim Women on the Veil
item.description: A recent New York Times article about Muslim women who wear veils yielded about 1,000 reader comments. “My veil has never stopped me from doing anything,” one woman said.
item.dc:creator: HANNA INGBER
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: France, where Muslims make up an estimated 8 percent of the population, has long displayed discomfort with Muslim women who cover their heads.

item.title: France Rejects Iran Leader’s Ban on Unlimited Nuclear Inspections
item.description: The French position came as negotiators reconvened with the aim of reaching a final agreement on the nuclear dispute by June 30.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: In a Five-Star Setting, FIFA Officials Are Arrested, the Swiss Way
item.description: The venerable Baur au Lac hotel, which overlooks Lake Zurich, provided an unlikely setting for the apprehension of six global soccer executives.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and SAM BORDEN
item.media:credit: Pascal Mora for The New York Times
item.media:description: Officials led FIFA officials, including Eduardo Li, out of the Baur au Lac hotel on Wednesday. Li was set to join FIFA’s powerful executive committee this weekend.

item.title: World Briefing: Tony Blair to Resign in June as Special Middle East Envoy
item.description: Representing the Middle East “quartet” of the United States, Russia, the United Nations and the European Union, he made little progress toward a lasting peace.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: FIFA Inquiry Yields Indictments; U.S. Officials Vow to Pursue More
item.description: As FIFA leaders gathered for a meeting, Swiss law enforcement officials arrived unannounced and made arrests at the Justice Department’s request on charges including racketeering and money laundering.
item.dc:creator: MATT APUZZO, STEPHANIE CLIFFORD and WILLIAM K. RASHBAUM
item.media:description: Jack Warner, a former FIFA vice president, is among those expected to face charges in the United States.

item.title: Other Foreigners Detained in Iran
item.description: In the past seven years, other journalists and American travelers have been arrested in Iran for spying. All have denied the accusations.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:credit: Robin Marchant/Getty Images; Vahid Salemi/Associated Press; Freeamir.org
item.media:description: From left: Maziar Bahari, Reza Taghavi and Amir Hekmati.

item.title: Jason Rezaian Trial in Iran May Be More About Leverage Than Justice
item.description: The fates of Americans imprisoned in Iran have often centered on how the country’s negotiations with the United States are going.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Q. and A.: As Jason Rezaian Stands Trial in Iran, Former Prisoners Share Their Experiences
item.description: Shane M. Bauer, Joshua F. Fattal and Roxana Saberi, three Americans convicted, imprisoned and later released by Iran, talk about their closed trials.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Shane M. Bauer, Sarah E. Shourd and Josh F. Fattal in Oakland, Calif., in 2011. They were arrested together in 2009 when they wandered across the border from Iraq into Iran.

item.title: Yemeni-Americans, Thrust Into Limbo, Say U.S. Embassy Unfairly Revokes Passports
item.description: American citizens, lawyers say, are essentially rendered stateless by the embassy in Sana, Yemen, for no apparent reason other than their Yemeni origin.
item.dc:creator: LIZ ROBBINS
item.media:description: Mosed Shaye Omar, 64, a naturalized American citizen since 1978, sued the State Department and Secretary John Kerry, claiming he was coerced into acknowledging that he had a name different from what was on his passport.
